content.webTitle: Akai Gurley death: NYPD officer pleads not guilty to manslaughter charge

fields.headline: Akai Gurley death: NYPD officer pleads not guilty to manslaughter charge
fields.bodyText: Officer Peter Liang stood motionless in court as the six charges against him, including second-degree manslaughter, were read out. Liang’s lawyer, Stephen Worth, spoke for him when returning the officer’s not guilty plea. The Asian American officer, a 27-year-old rookie, fired a single fatal shot as he opened the doorway of a stairwell during a nighttime patrol of the Pink Houses block in Brooklyn in November. It ricocheted off the wall and fatally struck 28 year-old Akai Gurley, an unarmed black man, in the chest. Liang had not been seen in public since the incident, but on Wednesday he appeared in court following a grand jury decision to indict him. The charges mark the first time in over two years that an NYPD officer has been indicted, and stand in stark contrast to the decisions in the Eric Garner and Michael Brown cases, where grand juries in New York and Missouri declined to indict officers for the deaths of unarmed black men. Liang was freed without bail, and left the court through the public gallery, wheresome of Gurley’s supporters heckled the officer as he walked past. “The whole damn system is guilty as hell. Indict, convict Peter Liang to jail,” they shouted. Prosecutors argued that the second-degree manslaughter charge, which carries a maximum of 15 years in prison, as well as charges of criminally negligent homicide, assault in the second degree, reckless endangerment in the second degree and two counts of official misconduct, were brought because Liang had “ignored training” by patrolling with his gun out and his finger on the trigger. At a press conference, Brooklyn district attorney Ken Thompson told reporters he did not believe Liang had intended to kill Gurley, “but he had his finger on the trigger and he fired the gun.” Thompson dismissed criticism from Liang’s lawyers that the charges were too severe, and described his investigation as “thorough and fair”. Thompson added that the investigation would not have been possible without the assistance of the NYPD, and paid homage to those officers who arrived on the scene after the shooting and “dropped to their knees and attempted to render aid to save Mr Gurley’s life”. Prosecutor Marc Fliedner told the court that Liang had stood for four minutes at the top of the stairwell after the shots were fired, and did not call the shot in – as is protocol. “I’m going to be fired,” Liang told his partner in that time, according to the prosecutor’s account. Gurley had descended down the stairwell and collapsed. A friend he was with attempted to perform CPR. Fliedner, however, dismissed as inaccurate reports by the New York Daily News that suggested Liang had texted his union instead of calling for medical assistance. A small group of protesters congregated outside the courtroom holding pictures of Gurley to honour his memory. Mars Acosta, a 31-year-old homeschooling mother who lives a few blocks from the site of Gurley’s death, told the Guardian she believed the indictment was only a small victory in a broader problem of police impunity. “I feel as if this is just an indictment to hush us up in the community. The system is very corrupt. We don’t only want to see just this indictment, we want to see justice for all the lives that have been taken away,” she said. “Justice will be served for Akai Gurley,” said Hertencia Petersen, Gurley’s 49-year-old aunt. “We will prevail.”
